awd_titl_txt: SPX: A Geometry and Architecture Agnostic Scalable Framework for N-body Problems with Oscillatory Potentials
awd_abstract_narration:
Solutions to equations governing electromagnetics and acoustics have enabled crucial technologies such as wireless communication devices, passive and active RF-IDs, optical and high-speed devices, sonar and radar emitters in automobiles, microwaves, medical diagnostic, and imaging tools, among several others. Advances in these technologies rely on understanding the underlying wave physics in sufficient detail. This task is increasingly challenging given the increase in geometric complexity (smaller and more complex features) and wider range of operating wave frequencies thereby requiring more precision and detail to achieve optimal performance. The primary goal of this project is to develop a geometry and architecture agnostic scalable framework for N-body problems with oscillatory (wave) potentials through synergistic research in both numerical methods and parallel algorithms. In collaboration with domain scientists, the resulting framework's utility will be demonstrated via applications in  electromagnetic radiation, acoustic imaging, and nano-photonics. In order to ensure the widest possible dissemination, outcomes of the proposed research including technical reports, codes, user manuals and test cases will be made available through a dedicated website. The interdisciplinary nature of this project will provide ample opportunities to train undergraduate and graduate students in leading edge research that cuts across applied mathematics, high performance computing, and electrical engineering.

The key enabler of the framework to be developed in this project is the Helmholtz (oscillatory potential) variant of the Fast Multipole Method (FMM). While rapid solution to Laplace equations using FMM has had a profound impact on several disciplines, from gravitational physics to molecular dynamics to geophysics to electrical engineering, the algorithms and software for the Helmholtz variant is lagging far behind. Leveraging massive parallelism to enable the evaluation of oscillatory potentials at unprecedented speed and scales forms the main intellectual contributions of this project. The project approach is comprised of the following objectives: (i) Development of an innovative adaptive numerical scheme to overcome the computational and memory bottlenecks of FMM for oscillatory potentials, (ii) Novel load balancing and auto-tuning algorithms optimized to achieve high performance for a given problem instance and hardware architecture, (iii) A hybrid parallel implementation that will leverage task parallelism to reduce communication overheads and achieve portability on emerging distributed memory architectures, and (iv) Evaluation of the capabilities and performance of the resulting software through multi-scale modeling of a diverse set of Helmholtz systems. The numerical methods and parallel algorithms developed in this project will be implemented in an open-source software called HFMM-XScale, which will be designed as a modular software for easy integration into existing domain specific solvers. As such, HFMM-XScale is anticipated to have a broad impact on the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project is to enable the evaluation of oscillatory potentials (for both frequency and time domain problems) over complex geometries at high performance on large supercomputers. Physics described by hyperbolic partial differential equations (PDEs) form the backbone of a wide array of technologies based on electromagnetics. However, our understanding of the underlying wave physics is limited due to the difficulty of solving the corresponding hyperbolic PDEs. This project has significantly expanded the reach of simulation tools for wave phenomena by developing novel algorithms, numerical methods and performance optimization techniques for Helmholtz variant of the Fast Multipole Method (FMM), which is also known as the multilevel fast multipole algorithm (MLFMA).

Our accomplishments can be summarized as follows: 

1- First, we developed a parallel wideband MLFMA algorithm the accuracy of which can be controlled to desired precision, even for problems with multi-scale features (for instance, a broadband antenna on a large airplane). The sampling of the spectrum is optimal in this algorithm and as such it overcomes memory bottlenecks associated with local inter/anterpolations.

2- Next, we built upon the initial version of our parallel wideband MLFMA algorithm. We addressed several challenges regarding parallelization and communication, and we demonstrated an efficient and scalable method for evaluation of the Helmholtz potential. In particular, we developed a fine-grain parallel algorithm with bottom-up partitioning that enables scalable evaluation of deep uniform MLFMA trees, while maintaining controllable accuracy of solutions to desired accuracies. We have also developed a detailed analytical model to characterize the complexity and memory use of the parallel algorithm for far-field interactions. We demonstrated that our new MLFMA implementation is one to two orders of magnitude faster than comparable implementations reported in the literature.

3- As a next step, we developed a hybrid parallel MLFMA algorithm to ensure  high-efficiency and scalability on distributed memory multi-core architectures. The hybrid parallel version was implemented using MPI for message passing between compute nodes and OpenMP for asynchronous many task execution within each node. Indeed, several benefits were observed, including increased parallel efficiency, improved load balancing, and faster execution times compared to a pure MPI implementation, but the most important benefit of the hybrid MPI/OpenMP approach has been the significant reductions in memory requirements for big problems. The hybrid approach exploits the shared memory of high performance computers and reduces the amount of duplicated data across processes. As such, we have been able to use our MLFMA code for computations involving problems with tens of millions of degrees of freedom. 

4- Determining how electromagnetic (EM) waves scatter boils down to solving a system of linear equations, Ax=b. The matrix A comes from an integral equation that describes the physics of the electromagnetic fields. The unknowns x can either be found through a direct inverse of the matrix A or by an indirect, iterative method. The MLFMA implementation described above actually constitutes the main kernel of these iterative solvers which are the only practical methods for simulating electrically large objects with millions of degrees of freedom. Therefore, we also addressed the issue of iterative solver convergence. The tradionally used Combined Field Integral Equation (CFIE) formulation is ill-conditioned and slowly converges in the simulation of real-world problems. New integral formulations were developed to solve this problem using Calderon projectors, Green's Second Identity, and the non-uniqueness of potential representations of electromagnetic phenomenology. These new formulations demonstrated drastically improved convergence properties for a collection of iterative solvers for real-world problems (very sharp pencils, bumpy cubes, asteroids) compared to conventional formulations.

Overall, this project has fulfilled its promise of creating solvers for electromagnetic problems that execute at unprecedented speed and scales. It has supported the PhD studies of 4 graduate students, and resulted in 6 published peer reviewed scientific articles in addition to three that are currently under review or under preparation. Additionally, our results were presented to the scientific community through several presentations in international conferences and public lectures.
